description.narrative:
Objective: to strengthen civil society capacities in 4 Afghan provinces in effectively resolving and mitigating conflict whilst enhancing the status and inclusion of women and opening a national debate on peace and conflict resolution.
The Building Afghan PeaceLocally programme is a multi- partner programme combining different approaches on the basis of ongoing programming funded by Oxfam Novib into one integrated programme implemented by six partner organisations; ADA, AWSDC, CHA, CoAR, CPAU/PTRO, and SMO. The programme has been developed in order to submit to a EC call which was granted. The total amount of the programme (€ 958,539) will be covered by EC and the remaining by Oxfam Novib. Oxfam Novib will coordinate the project from the Country Office in Kabul.
Envisaged results are 1. In 8 districts across 4 provinces, local civil society and governance actors have established effective and socially inclusive peacebuilding structures. This service will be in reach for aprox. 835,000 people living in the districts. Objective: to strengthen civil society capacities in 4 Afghan provinces in effectively resolving and mitigating conflict whilst enhancing the status and inclusion of women and opening a national debate on peace and conflict resolution.
Building Afghan Peace Locally is a multi- partner programme combining different approaches on the basis of ongoing programming funded by the EC and Oxfam Novib into one integrated six partner interventions: ADA, AWSDC, CHA, CoAR, CPAU/PTRO, and SMO. The total amount of the programme (€ 958,539) will be covered by EC and the remaining by Oxfam Novib. Oxfam Novib will coordinate the project from the Country Office in Kabul.
results 1. In 8districts across 4 provinces, local civil society and governance actors have established effective and socially inclusive peacebuilding structures. This service will be in reach for aprox. 835,000 people living in the districts.
2. In target districts, the role of women in local peace and conflict issues hasbeen systematically addressed and gender equality has been improved
3 . Research anddocumentation of models has promoted best practice in linking state and non-state actors in peacebuilding, illustrating how women can play an active role in civil society and particularly in peacebuilding
4. Lobbying based on practical experience, research and popular mobilisation has helped bring about changes in policy and practice of the Afghan authorities:
Spin offs: - Currently the Afghan government’s main focus is on the reconciliation process with little recognition of the role local conflict play in the national conflict. This programme with its strong advocacy and campaigning component will be able to inform and disseminate divers programme experiences to both afghan government and public, which can lead to the Afghan government recognizing the need for local peace building and enforcing a national strategy. - The programme will strengthen local mechanisms for conflict transformation ensuring inclusion of women (both as victims as actors) and minorities. These groups in the past have often been negatively affected by local level conflict resolution mechanisms. Especially girls and women are used to reconcile between households in conflict. Further, the recognition within communities as well as at government level the specific circumstances women were and are affected by conflict is an important milestone to further integrate women in conflict resolution and peace building efforts.

participating-org.narrative: SABA Media Organization (SMO) is a cultural, social and non-for-profit media organization. SABA started its operation in 1997 underthe aegis of CHA, as a monthly periodical in Peshawar with the name 'Saba Magazine'. The SABA media organisation was established tofacilitate the development of capacities and the sustainability of free media initiatives in Afghanistan, and in the long-term to contribute to improving the quality of services. SABA's mission is to assist in the sustainable development of Afghan society throughawareness raising and education of Afghan citizens on creating a society of peace, solidarity and stability. Awareness raising and education of Afghan citizens is a cross-cutting issue in SMO. SMO#s core activities are: to conduct co-ordinated and effective activities for improving and developing the cultural, literary and artistic aspects of Afghan society; to raise the awareness of Afghans through radio, television, printed materials and websites; to conduct technical and professional training for Afghans on culture, art and journalism in order to raise the number of cadres; to produce audiovisual material in local and national languages; to publish books and other academic writings. SMO#s head office is based in Kabul. Nawa radio and SMO#s television broadcasting reaches almost all provinces in the country. SMO#s major donors have been European Union, the Royal Netherland Embassy, UNDP/AJDL, UNDP/ACT, UNIFEM, the Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade (DFAIT), Canada National, the Endowment for Democracy, the Open Society Institute, Right and Democracy, Oxfam GB in Afghanistan, the Human Rights Research and Advocacy Consortium, and Oxfam Novib

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
